raw: * This class is the single point to access all settings that may be different
* in different environments. This contains e.g. the browser name, engine
* version but also qooxdoo or application specific settings.
* Its public API can be found in its four main methods. One pair of methods
* is used to check the synchronous values of the environment. The other pair
* of methods is used for asynchronous checks.
* The most often used method should be {@link #get}, which returns the
* current value for a given environment check.
* All qooxdoo settings can be changed at compile time. See the manual
* for more details about the environment key in the config. As you can see
* from the methods API, there is no way to override an existing key. So if you
* need to change a qooxdoo setting, you have to use the compiler to do so.
* The compiler is also responsible for requiring the necessary implementation
* classes for each check. When using a check of a new category, make sure to
* rebuild you application and let the compiler include the necessary files.
* When you define a new environment check, the compiler needs to know which class
* implements the check; to do this, you can either prefix the name of your check
* with your class name (eg `my.package.MyClass.someEnvCheck`) or you can create
* short names like the ones below and then add an entry to your library's
* The following table shows the available checks. If you are
* interested in more details, check the reference to the implementation of
* each check. Please do not use those check implementations directly, as the
* Environment class comes with a smart caching feature.

* css.transformObject or null{3d: true, origin: "WebkitTransformOrigin", name: "WebkitTransform", style: "WebkitTransformStyle", perspective: "WebkitPerspective", perspective-origin: "WebkitPerspectiveOrigin", backface-visibility: "WebkitBackfaceVisibility"}
* default locale C as in good tradition of unix {@link qx.bom.client.Locale}
* default: false Whether the environment is headless (ie rhino/nodejs); note that
*        headless will still have some kind of DOM emulation - normally that would be quite basic, unless
* The qx.headless allows code to detect whether there is an user interface, most typically
*        whether to cater for input events.  This is set automatically by the compiler but would have to be
* manually configured if you use the generator.
* true to enable runtime warnings in promises {@link qx.Promise}
* true to enable long stack traces in promises; this has a performance penalty but makes debugging asynchronous functions easier {@link qx.Promise}
* true if the corresponding optimize key is set in the config
* true if the corresponding optimize key is set in the config
* true if the corresponding optimize key is set in the config
* true if the corresponding optimize key is set in the config
* true if the corresponding optimize key is set in the config
* true if the corresponding optimize key is set in the config

@description.name: @description
@description.body:
This class is the single point to access all settings that may be different in different environments. This contains e.g. the browser name, engine version but also qooxdoo or application specific settings. Its public API can be found in its four main methods. One pair of methods is used to check the synchronous values of the environment. The other pair of methods is used for asynchronous checks. The most often used method should be {@link #get}, which returns the current value for a given environment check. All qooxdoo settings can be changed at compile time. See the manual for more details about the environment key in the config. As you can see from the methods API, there is no way to override an existing key. So if you need to change a qooxdoo setting, you have to use the compiler to do so. The compiler is also responsible for requiring the necessary implementation classes for each check. When using a check of a new category, make sure to rebuild you application and let the compiler include the necessary files. When you define a new environment check, the compiler needs to know which class implements the check; to do this, you can either prefix the name of your check with your class name (eg my.package.MyClass.someEnvCheck) or you can create short names like the ones below and then add an entry to your library's Manifest.json (under provides.environmentChecks). The following table shows the available checks. If you are interested in more details, check the reference to the implementation of each check. Please do not use those check implementations directly, as the Environment class comes with a smart caching feature.

Synchronous checks

Key

Type

Example

The qx.headless allows code to detect whether there is an user interface, most typically whether to cater for input events. raw: * The default accessor for the checks. It returns the value the current
* environment has for the given key. The key could be something like
* checks can be found in the class comment of this class.
* Please keep in mind that the result is cached. If you want to run the
* check function again in case something could have been changed, take a
* @param key {String} The name of the check you want to query.
* @return {var} The stored value depending on the given key.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: The default accessor for the checks. It returns the value the current environment has for the given key. The key could be something like "qx.debug", "css.textoverflow" or "io.ssl". A complete list of checks can be found in the class comment of this class. Please keep in mind that the result is cached. If you want to run the check function again in case something could have been changed, take a look at the {@link #invalidateCacheKey} function.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: key {String} The name of the check you want to query.
@param.description: The name of the check you want to query.

raw: * Internal helper which tries to pick the given key from the given values
* map. If that key is not found, it tries to use a key named "default".
* If there is also no default key, it prints out a warning and returns
* @param key {String} The key to search for in the values.
* @param values {Map} A map containing some keys.
* @return {var} The value stored as values[key] usually.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Internal helper which tries to pick the given key from the given values map. If that key is not found, it tries to use a key named "default". If there is also no default key, it prints out a warning and returns undefined.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: key {String} The key to search for in the values.
@param.description: The key to search for in the values.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: values {Map} A map containing some keys.

@return.name: @return
@return.body: {var} The value stored as values[key] usually.

raw: * Takes a given map containing the check names as keys and converts
* the map to an array only containing the values for check evaluating
* to true. This is especially handy for conditional
* @param map {Map} A map containing check names as keys and values.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Takes a given map containing the check names as keys and converts the map to an array only containing the values for check evaluating to true. This is especially handy for conditional includes of mixins.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: map {Map} A map containing check names as keys and values.
